With the stress of college admissions, students’ schedules are becoming more and more jam-packed with event after event, meeting after meeting, rehearsal after rehearsal, volunteering after volunteering...the list goes on...all on top of piles of homework and the pressure to succeed academically. However, it’s important to stay in touch with your personal interests and actively engage in your hobbies.
There are several mental benefits to having and keeping up with a hobby. Research shows that people who practice their hobbies feel happier and more relaxed, and are less likely to suffer from low mood, stress, and depression.
Hobbies also help to structure your time. When you set aside time to practice our hobby, there’s less time in the day to spend doing more frivolous things that require less time, such as replying to emails or laboring over a project. Simply put, scheduling time for hobbies encourages efficiency, which can alleviate the stress caused by dragging things out.
Having a hobby makes you more interesting and can help foster social connections, which have been shown to be key to feeling happy. It can create a common ground between you and others that you otherwise wouldn’t normally engage with and can give you something interesting to talk about.
There are thousands of different hobbies, but here are just a few general ones in case you’re having trouble finding the right one. Hobbies vary from person to person and may be academic, creative, academic or something distinctly personal.
1. Exercise. Physical activity causes the brain and other parts of the nervous system to release endorphins, neurotransmitters that are partially responsible for positive feelings, thus naturally combating depression. Experts say that exercising is a good way for those suffering from mild or moderate depression to cope, so it might not be the answer for those who are severely depressed. Additionally, exercise can become unhealthy if done incorrectly or in excess, so it is important to establish a healthy and doable workout. It can be as simple as completing a short routine during study breaks, or a complex as going to the gym or taking workout classes. If there’s time on the weekends, you can even go hiking or try something like new like surfing so as to both boost your endorphins and physically distance yourself from the stress of school.
2. Journaling. Whether it be physical or digital, daily or just when you need to let it all out, journaling is a great way to purge your feelings from your mind and let them spill out on paper (or a digital document). Writing out your feelings and frustrations can also help you think through them more clearly and rationally, helping you come to better conclusions in a healthier way. Journaling doesn’t have to take up a whole lot of time either; you can write anything from a few sentences to several pages— whatever it takes for you to feel better.
3. Making art or music. Even if you don’t see yourself as the “artist” type, you can still pick up a pen and get to doodling or learn to play a new instrument through online lessons! Making art/music not only gets your creativity flowing, but can also be a great stress-reliever, allowing you to unleash your feelings in a more artistic manner.
If these activities don’t work for you, keep trying new things until you find something (or some things) that you enjoy and that is meaningful to you! Some other possible hobbies include woodworking, cooking/baking, creative writing, knitting, and crafting, but there are so many more hobbies out there, and you don’t have to pick just one! The important thing is that you are engaging in a fun, interesting activity that you can use to take your mind off the stress of school and day-to-day life.
